From Roy A. Graham (with permission):

Those who have an interest in maintaining the status quo have never welcomed the voices that declare in favor of the poor and disadvantaged. The silence of the Press in regard to the complicity of the rich in the downpression of the poor is the inevitable function of a system of patronage that is the raison d’être of the Press itself. Christianity as we know it is a reflection of the prevailing moral values in society to the extent that prophetic voices are invariably isolated and targeted for elimination. The false equivalencies that we witness are noting more than attempts to muddle the consciousness of those who are patrons of the daily discourse of charlatans “making a living”.

Owner of the NBA’s Sacramento Clippers Tells His Girl Friend, “Don’t Bring Blacks To My Games!”

In a 9 minute audio clip, the Clippers owner shares his world view on race; in turns claiming love for black people, telling his girl friend she doesn’t understand the culture and only wants to fight, to pleading with her to have no public contact with African-Americans, and not to bring "them" to his games. Click below to hear the exchange (given to TMZ).

NBA Owner Donald Sterling Tells His Mexican/African-American Girl Friend: "You Are The Enemy!": [http://wp.me/p1mBVu-381].
It is an old and useful black community axiom, many elders shared, that you don't chase after stray dogs no matter how loudly they yelp.

It's Europe. I remember working a project for a German company. They insisted that we buy only German equipment. I thought, so much for the European Union. The German will hide as cowards until Putin's on their border, after greedily devouring first the Ukrainians, then the Romanians and finally the Poles. Of course, we should let them go to the dogs but by that time the American bankers will be pushing us to save their portfolio.

This junk about NATO interceptor missiles on the border of Russia negating its nuclear deterrence has been refuted multiple times in the past; the program to station such in Poland/Czech Republic was scrapped back in 2009, there are no US ABM systems currently on European territory, there would not be enough interceptors to overcome all of the Russian land-based ICBMs and the interceptors are incapable of doing anything at all to counter the large number of ICBMs on Russian submarines or nukes on cruise missiles that would be launched from aircraft. The conjectured anti-ballistic missiles in Europe were intended to counter a few ICBMs fired from Iran or N Korea and the program has nothing to do with NATO.

The scrapped proposal for the placement of the ABMs was between the US, Poland and Czech Republic. It is now proposed that an ABM system be placed in Romania in 2015 and Poland in 2018. And again, these systems would not be capable of countering all of Russia's land based ICBMs.

If there is or is not a Russian surveillance ship has nothing to do with nuclear missiles, ICBMs are intended to strike any point of the earth from any launch point, the Russians do not need missiles in Cuba, you are talking about 1960s technology which has been long superseded, and Russian nukes in Cuba would undoubtably violate the treaties between Russian and the US governing nuclear missiles. If the Russian's want to place nukes off the US coast then they have submarines to do that.

The Parliament that was elected by all of Ukraine, both east and west, before Yanukovych's dismissal, is still in place. It is not an illegal government and it does not just represent 12% of the population.

It is time that President Obama and Secretary of State John Kerry  use every means available to force compliance regarding sanctions.  The current crisis has turned into a charm offensive by the Russians as they are meeting with the EU reminding them that they too have an alliance with Russia; one that is symbiotic and longstanding; and the current crisis should not be allowed to disrupt that relationship. President Obama must do what he dislikes doing and that is playing the political game.  He must seek compliance and remind the EU that the US has met every obligation to defend Europe and it  is the major contributor and actor in NATO. In this current crisis he must insist and use any political and diplomatic means to gain compliance. If the EU is not on board, Ukraine will be lost as well as the credibility of an EU -US alliance!
Uh, let's see: because it's the right thing to do?

You do not seem to grasp the principal of fiduciary responsibility.  If Buffet believed that the compensation plan was inappropriate, it was his legal responsibility to vote against it.  Imagine for instance a corporate action that was potentially dangerous to the well being of the company (think Enron!).  If a the head of an investment group believed the action was wrong, but still voted for it (or didn't vote against it), he could be charged with a violation of his fiduciary responsibility to his investors.

Kenarmy,

Fiduciary responsibility means acting in the best interest of Warren's shareholders, not other Coke shareholders. Perhaps Warren believes that the Coke will be most profitable for his shareholders because not angering the management means he could eventually buy it down the road.

Warren Buffett has made a fortune betting on Coca Cola, with at least one report estimating that he has made a 766% return on investment since he started purchasing shares in 1988 (http://xfinity.comcast.net/slideshow/finance-buffetsbestinvestmentsever/....
When a company has performed so well for you for several decades, why interfere with the management? Further, if Buffett didn't feel that the compensation plan would be ultimately voted down (Berkshire Hathaway has a 9% stake) as they rarely are, why waste political capital for a losing cause?
No, our education system has failed if we are entertained by Fox News.

I was in the UK recently. Someone there asked me if Americans were really daft enough to believe Fox News or if they were just watching it for laughs.

The people I met in the UK knew more about American politics than most Americans I encounter. They're shocked by the behavior of Republicans and baffled by the people who put them in office.

Education is much better there.

Bundy and his cohorts sure do show how truly ignorant we are in this nation of ours.   We can excuse the media because Fox News is a misnomer for Fox Entertainment.   Hannity has to entertain and not necessarily inform.  Unfortunately, his audience does not understand that.  The tragedy is that so many so called political leaders trotted over to hail Bundy as an American Hero.  Our educational system has failed if people cannot see the truth from the entertainment.   But hey, it was funny to see so many doing the backstroke away from Bundy.   And maybe that was the real news finding out the puppets that we have running our government.

Mr. Chamberlain? Is that you? "Peace in our time" you say?

In fact, you're worse than Mr. Chamberlain. You've not just given up Crimea and the Donbass, both of which Russia has already invaded militarily, but also the rest of Ukraine as well. This is like telling the Czechs to just give Hitler Prague after he's taken the Sudatenland. Ethical cowardice at its worst.

So, the people in Ukraine should have no say about what happens to their country. Is that correct? The world should just sit by while it is carved up like a Thanksgiving turkey.

As for your next up, that would be Alaska. Don't forget, that used to be Russia. So, we should just sign it over now and get it over with. No need to bother trying to defend it.

The Russian point of view regarding Ukraine is that it is in their sphere of influence. They regard Ukraine as part of their glorious historic past. In order for them to restore their nationalistic pride they are willing to go to any lengths in the pursuit of that goal.
There is no such existential belief in the West Dysfunctional Europe will immediately go for the fast buck and self absorbed Americans could care less about Ukraine or anywhere else for that matter.
Consequently, the faster the Obama Administration cuts a deal to limit the aspirations of the aggrieved & aggressive Russian Bear the better off we all will be.
There is no future in taking this one on........we have neither the desire, the will or the means to prevent Ukraine from being absorbed. Any support to that beleaguered Country would only be postponing the inevitable. Cut the losses. Next up......the Balkans.

We're fans of the Oracle, and what he looks to be doing here is providing us a primer on out-of-whack corporate governance.

He tells us that never in 55 years of sitting on boards of directors has he seen a compensation committee plan voted down.

And the story also gives us the facts about share-holders trying to marshal institutional ' no ' votes, as well as Buffett's idea that Coca-Cola's plan was excessive.

And yet, all Buffett could do was abstain.

Now, that may be enough to change things at Coca-Cola, and elsewhere in corporate America.

But what Buffett's 55 years of director-ships point out is the affinity fraud which is rampant in the round-robin of corporate CEO's compensating themselves - the same type of affinity fraud that was highlighted in the Madoff fiasco.

Things have been trending the wrong way in corporate governance, with news items about Delaware Chancery Court wanting to rent out its judges and court-rooms for secret corporate proceedings:

http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/01/opinion/renting-judges-for-secret-ruli...

as Judith Resnick helpfully detailed regarding the Chancery Court's appeal to the Citizens United Court that ' balls and strikes ' Roberts is presiding over.
The bigger problem is his allies will vote in 2014 and the progressive turnout will probably be low. Please help get out the vote in 2014!
Speaking of mouth breathers, there's not a dimes worth of difference between Bundy and Sharpton. Except you never hear a word out of Blow about Sharpton's toxic racism. Wonder why?

"...they can demonstrate that they're truly and genuinely lacking in racial prejudice."

Stu,

The contrary point can't be made often enough. Sean Hannity has no need to demonstrate to you or anyone else that he lacks racial prejudice. I can only conclude that the view you express here, with which so many apparently agree, results from a lack of serious reading which challenges your own political views.

If you do that reading you will quickly find out that there are compelling arguments - supported by fact - on the other side of many hot issues of the day. But you seldom get the whole of an argument from a television show, so don't expect to see a case laid out in its entirety and defended against major counter-arguments on Hannity's program. There just isn't time no matter how well versed his guests.

But the larger point is that posts like yours are anti-intellectual in the sense that they smear people who happen to have differing, honestly-held views from your own. If people like you really believe that affirmative action and Obamacare are open and shut non-issues which only racists can oppose, then we all should fear for the future of a free and open politics in this country.

Problem is that right-wing mouthbreathers like Hannity seem to feel that by disassociating themselves from white-hooded neanderthals like Bundy they can demonstrate that they're truly and genuinely lacking in racial prejudice.  Then they can go ahead and take up the Bundy agenda by railing against affirmative action, poverty programs, the Affordable Care Act and anything else that might actually enable black Americans to discard the yoke of all-American racism.  Just because our society has advanced out of the 1860s doesn't mean that social justice has improved much beyond the 1960s.

Under International Law, a victorious belligerent may retain captured land, until modified by treaty. If no treaty is made, the victor retains the land. The post World War II occupations of Germany and Japan ended with peace treaties. If, and when, this one ends, it will end the same way. See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uti_possidetis

Hamas and the Taliban are equal players in the effort to bring Allah
and his warriors to the non believers. Hamas is a more localized army for this crusade. Once the Islamic faith becomes the law of the land, then and only then, will this war come to an end. Hamas is the first, to not only admit this but feverishly defends their pronouncements and sees as their G*d given role the removal of every Jew that walks on the earth. Anti-Semites are the only ones that find this simple fact impossible to understand.

How does that compare to: Americans are captive to many sloppy mental habits, not the least of which is their disdain for the application of the same standards they like to be measured with to others.

As deplorable as the excuses of German businessman are, at least they have some reason for mealymouthness. I recently read a quote, I believe from Helmut Kohl, that shrugged off the annexation of Crimea as old news. I wonder if he would be as cavalier if Crimea were annexed by another country with which it has an even longer history, Turkey?

Europeans are captive to many sloppy mental habits, not the least of which is their disdain for the United States. They don't have to like us, but they should be honest with themselves about Mr. Putin.

Business interest are what makes our Democracy work the way it works.
Business have always run the governments; money talks. Remember the British when they owned us and when the British East India Company went worldwide doing the bidding for the Royalty. If the money is not with you nothing would change.

"Business interests" have seldom been a guide for how a nation ought to conduct itself.  Instead of paying attention to "business interests" the UK ought to make it clear that if Russia invades Ukraine, ALL of the real estate and other holdings of Russian Oligarchs in London and elsewhere will be nationalized.  That should concentrate their minds.

c.k. Chen:  Bush may have bungled after the overthrow of Saddam, and foolish in failing to  see how the Sunni would react to his overthrow of a government that had  out   their interests ahead of the majority Shiites, but after years of stumbling , Bush was finally able to sustain an Iraqi government with some checks and balances. But we were the buffer that kept the religion  factions from colliding, and Obama was totally against any real effort to negotiate a status of forces agreement that would keep  US presence in the country as an honest broker but also to prevent growing Iranian influence in the Shiite majority government. Obama bugged out, with something of the same result as the British bug-out of Palestine in 1947.  Obama has no interest in foreign policy, or his world view is the simplistic anti-colonialsm some have attributed to him, which is less Marxist in character than Fabian.like that of the Labour Government that came in in 1945.

It is simplistic to say that the Fox pundits and Republicans hate the federal government. They had no problem with the federal gov't when Bush was president. They seem to hate the federal gov't when Democrats, led by the mixed race Obama, run it and when those Dems use that gov't to try to make health care affordable, to make voting easier and elections fairer, to preserve food stamps for the poor and union rights for working people, to raise the minimum wage, to make college affordable, etc. In short to help hurting Americans.

The Republicans' agenda is about preserving and augmenting the political and economic power of the 1%. Because of that overriding objective, Republicans have embraced some extremist views and people in order to win votes. Enter Bundy who is sticking his thumb to the government while also attracting that vital Second Amendment constituency. He seemed like the poster child for Republican wedge issues. Too bad for the Republicans that the media just left the mic's open and the cameras on to catch his racist antebellum rants.

Something else we've learned: How the far right wing in this country thinks and acts.
Believe it now?
Yes, one such incident resulted in  Wounded Knee, another in a massacre of black men and women in Philadelphia.

"So, what have we learned from the Crazy Rancher Guy saga?"

We have learned that he has been freeloading for a couple of decades at the expense of taxpayers in general and his fellow ranchers in particular.

We have learned that he and his bunch of armed malcontent supporters claim not to recognize the Federal government but have no trouble quoting the constitution and waving the Stars and Stripes.

We have learned that many pundits and politicians who fled from his racist version of history still share his hate of the federal government.

We have learned from the NYT* that one such politician in particular has a book out entitled: “Government Bullies: How Everyday Americans Are Being Harassed, Abused and Imprisoned by the Feds.” When a would-be President sets out to inflame such feelings, is it any wonder that Crazy Rancher Guys and Crazy Gun Guys come out of the woodwork?

And finally: let's imagine that this hadn't been a bitter old white rancher with a private army facing the feds, but a black or native American with some real or imagined grievance. How, I wonder, would the right-wing media-political complex have reacted then?

*http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/25/us/politics/paul-and-wealthy-libertari...

Fox News has become exactly what it and its adherents once said they despised, a shill for political causes, right instead of left. Whatever left leaning "liberal media" we might have once had, they were never this bad. The truth couldn't get through to Fox with a bulldozer and a tank leading the way. It is "state media" (a government sponsored, "official" outlet) waiting for the moment when the state is fully in the hands of the right wing. Why would anyone want to create a slightly snappier, right wing version of Soviet media? Didn't that experiment meet with a rather sad end?

Police departments and western state governments have a big problem, however, in putting down armed and unarmed "demonstrators" of the radical right: they face their own people, brothers-in-arms, across the potential firing line. It is not as simple as gassing and loading up a lot of superannuated hippies, eco-freaks and tree huggers. The confrontation was interesting if for no other reason that it set our increasingly militarized police armies back on their heels. For a change. We might have seen a glimpse of our future.
Sometimes you can't buy respect with all the money in the world.

Trying to shame people who have no shame seems at best an exercise in futility.

It is also particularly telling that collegiality trumps sound business management practices. Compensation committees are notoriously subject to conflicts of interest - they are hired by the folks whose compensation they determine. Imagine what your salary would be if you could fire the person that turned down your request for a raise - and how long your company could pay those inflated salaries before going into bankruptcy.

But, fear not - unlike the retired public servants of Detroit, the oligarchs' bloated salaries are safely beyond the reach of the bankruptcy courts. They merely suck the company dry, run it through bankruptcy to shed the bills owed to the "little people" (like your retirement fund), whine about how they are demonized and misunderstood - and head back to the trough for more and higher salaries.

Wags, There's a SLEW of Violins out there in the Streets, that's why we delight in taking refuge here in the relative quietude of WP!

Howie

The Republican majority has redefined the process of talking loud but saying nothing. The budget deficit is slowly being reduced, the economy is improving and there is some belief that the country may improve in areas of environmental regulation that benefits business and begins the process of reducing agents of climate pollution.
Capital projects are needed to fund these initiatives and yet the House majority and their supporters will not do what is necessary, appropriate and just.
Sadly this is no Girl Scout flogging Thin Mints, so I'd go with "kooky" vs. "cooky"... otherwise - right on.
As we have seen in the Islamic world, killing terrorists just makes more of them.  Dragon's teeth.

I hope that Mr. Bundy and his cooky "cause" just fall off the radar and, above all, that there is no fight to the death, because I fear the influence of him and like-minded outliers are much stronger posthumously than in life.  I remember that the Texan who flew his plane into a local IRS office and killed an innocent person, along with his own "pound of flesh," had admirers who sympathized with his bureaucratic grievances.  The violence which ended the Waco standoff produced new admirers of David Koresh. These sorts deserve no such glorification from dying, nor importance from their actions in life.
Agree! Let's go NYT. Follow the money.

IaMissy, how do you say in Spanish, "Let's see what the results are of privatizing education."  I think you will notice great improvement.  Public education is not the foundation of democracy, by the way, our Constitution is.
Education is necessary to a  functioning democracy, but it does not have to be public education. The educational function falls naturally into the spheres of he family and the church.

It's well past time for our country's newspaper of record to shine a light on all that the Waltons (and their fellow unelected plutocrats) are doing to charterize,  privatize and destabilize the foundation of our democracy, our public schools.  As we say in Spanish, más vale tarde que nunca.

Agreed, in fact with the undue attention to the natural gas market, people overlook that an equal amount of exports to Europe is in petrol where the alternative sources are far more readily available and the price effect of losing the Russian source would be marginal (its actually an area where US exports could help in the short-term, unlike liquified natural gas).  If Russia were allowed to continue shipping natural gas but no other energy exports to the EU, we would see a 25% cut in the funds available to the Russian military.

@Laura: this article is trying to find something nefarious in a huge corporation that is donating hundreds of millions of dollars to failing public school districts and supporting Teach For America -- the horror! the horror!

You'd think they were backing Cliven Bundy for Congress.

Meanwhile, Bill Gates' Foundation, which also gives money for schools, gets a total pass.

In my community, the Gates Foundation gave a huge sum for the "Smaller Schools Initiative". It broke our high school up into four smaller schools, with the goal of more intimacy, school spirit and achievement. It was a total failure that has since been rescinded, and the results were dismal. Results? remember those? that matters too.

Since Bill Gates is a LIBERAL billionaire, though, he gets a total pass.

With the extreme amount of money in the hands of the Walton offspring why don't they open private schools that are free to underprivileged children? After they have extorted so much money from the government by forcing their employees to seek public assistance, it is the least they could do. Why should taxpayers support this?
Laura from Sacramento couldn't resist bringing up the conservative bogeyman, Unions. As if all of the problems in our inner city schools would disappear if we could eliminate those pesky Unions. Angels would come out of the sky and teach our children for free. If we really valued education in this country we would have always treated teachers as true professionals. They would not have had to organize for economic justice.

"Kudos to the Walton family and their foundation, well done"? Perhaps if the Waltons actually paid their workers a fair living wage and did not rely on US taxpayers to "subsidize" their work force then we might consider them a credible source but that is not the case....seriously look into their corrupt business practices and then see if you think the Waltons are such wonderful & generous people, they are not, they are a takers and have their own agenda.

I want more details about attendance and student retention. The schools refuse to divulge data, so it makes it difficult to compare charters to traditional public schools.

This year, California isn't giving the CST, by which we have been judged in the past, so we haven't had the spring semester dump of failing charter students on traditional schools, like in past years. I expect this will start up again once common core testing begins in earnest.

It seems both sides are reluctant of their commitments and the consequences of those commitments.Putin seems determined to have his showdown with the West.America and her European allies are determined that Putin's action must be met by a strong reaction.There will hard consequences and feelings on both sides.I've heard heard one former Russian official assert that Putin is bluffing,but that he is a very good bluffer,whatever that means.I would think,as ex-KGB,now FSB,Putin's geopolitical stratagems are confined to confrontational winners and losers.Compromise and cooperative agreements are a strain on the hard world Putin envisions.Beyond military intervention,financial and economic hardship may be agents that demand an amendment of his world view.That remains to be seen.
